segments.en: Linked Discourses 3
3. Kosala
22. Grandmother
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: King Pasenadi of Kosala sat to one side, and the Buddha said to him,

segments.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, āgacchasi divādivassā”ti?
segments.en: “So, great king, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

segments.pli: “Ayyikā me, bhante, kālaṅkatā jiṇṇā vuḍḍhā mahallikā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā.
segments.en: “Sir, my grandmother has passed away. She was old, elderly and senior. She was advanced in years and had reached the final stage of life; she was a hundred and twenty years old.

segments.pli: Ayyikā kho pana me, bhante, piyā hoti manāpā.
segments.en: But I loved my grandmother; she was dear to me.

segments.pli: Hatthiratanena cepāhaṃ, bhante, labheyyaṃ ‘mā me ayyikā kālamakāsī’ti, hatthiratanampāhaṃ dadeyyaṃ:
segments.en: If by giving away the elephant treasure I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.

segments.pli: Assaratanena cepāhaṃ, bhante, labheyyaṃ ‘mā me ayyikā kālamakāsī’ti, assaratanampāhaṃ dadeyyaṃ:
segments.en: If by giving away the horse treasure I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.

segments.pli: Gāmavarena cepāhaṃ, bhante, labheyyaṃ ‘mā me ayyikā kālamakāsī’ti, gāmavarampāhaṃ dadeyyaṃ:
segments.en: If by giving away a prize village I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.

segments.pli: Janapadapadesena cepāhaṃ, bhante, labheyyaṃ ‘mā me ayyikā kālamakāsī’ti, janapadapadesampāhaṃ dadeyyaṃ:
segments.en: If by giving away the whole country I could get my grandmother back, I’d do it.”

segments.pli: ‘Sabbe sattā, mahārāja, maraṇadhammā maraṇapariyosānā maraṇaṃ anatītā’ti.
segments.en: “Great king, all sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.”
“It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing,
how well said this was by the Buddha:

segments.pli: sabbe sattā maraṇadhammā maraṇapariyosānā maraṇaṃ anatītā’”ti.
segments.en: ‘All sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.’”
“That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!

segments.pli: Sabbe sattā maraṇadhammā maraṇapariyosānā maraṇaṃ anatītā.
segments.en: All sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, yāni kānici kumbhakārabhājanāni āmakāni ceva pakkāni ca sabbāni tāni bhedanadhammāni bhedanapariyosānāni bhedanaṃ anatītāni;
segments.en: It’s like the vessels made by potters. Whatever kind they are, whether baked or unbaked, all of them are liable to break apart. Breaking is their end; they’re not exempt from breakage.

segments.pli: evameva kho, mahārāja, sabbe sattā maraṇadhammā maraṇapariyosānā maraṇaṃ anatītā”ti.
segments.en: In the same way, all sentient beings are liable to die. Death is their end; they’re not exempt from death.”
That is what the Buddha said. …
“All beings will die,
for life ends with death.
They pass on according to their deeds,
reaping the fruits of good and bad.
Those who do bad go to hell,
and if you do good you go to heaven.
That’s why you should do good,
investing in the future life.
The good deeds of sentient beings
support them in the next world.”

suttaplex.blurb: Pasenadi laments the death of his aged grandmother.
